BE11:21am

Thomas Cook saved? Yes, but not for the shareholders. Today’s announcement of a recapitalization effectively admits failure in the process to sell the airline, with weakening economics the main point (a profit warning has been thrown in for good measure). Therefore, the only option to save the business and address liquidity issues into this winter has been for Fosun to inject £750m (and take control of the tour operator) and for debt holders to swap into equity (and presumably control the airline). It is hard to imagine this scenario results in current equity holders getting out with anything of value (our guess, a lower class share with zero dividend) and the press release suggests best hope might be to take part in the recapitalization.

BE11:25am

Terms not clear, but proposal looks comprehensive
At this stage there is no clarity beyond the total £750m number: How much in equity? How much underwritten by FOSUN alone or any other / new strategic shareholders? How much in bank debt vs debt-to-equity swap offered to bond holders? And crucially, on what terms? What is clear is that this would be closer to a comprehensive refinancing to end all refinancings, after two less comprehensive attempts at £400m in 2016 and £90m in 2015.
Downside now likely limited, upgrade to Neutral
Our Underperform thesis since initiating on Thomas Cook shares on 10 April was based on a view that: 1) earnings downgrades would actually matter more than refinancing newsflow; and 2) selling the Airline would be a “once in a decade strategic mistake” doing away with product differentiation.
By hinting at an imminent capital structure fix and offering a package large enough to not require
asset sales, this announcement does not leave much more downside in our view, with the shares already down -55% year-to-date. We upgrade our rating to Neutral. We would consider reevaluating the upside in Thomas Cook shares once we get more clarity on the terms of the refinancing and confirmation that the Airline stays within the group.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Here comes Peel Hunt to summarise the gist of it.

BE11:33am

H1 profit expected to be c£29m. Lookers has guided to H1 PBT of c£32m before the change in accounting for intangibles (now included within adj profit), which equates to £29m under the on-going treatment, below our previous forecast of £36m. New car sales have remained challenging. UK new car registrations were down 4.6% over Q2 according to SMMT data, which is in keeping with our forecasts. However, the headline numbers are believed to have been supported by fairly high levels of pre-registrations, something that Lookers has avoided. Consequently, while new car margins have held up well, we believe sales levels have been below the market run rate.

BE11:33am

Used car prices how fallen by 8% over June. Demand for used cars weakened in June, resulting in a sharp correction in used car prices, which is still ongoing, we understand. For Lookers, the impact comes through as stock write downs, impacting gross margins. Used car gross profit and margins were up 2% at the end of Q1, but will finish the half down yoy. Forecast downgrades. H1 PBT has been guided to a level which is c£6-7m below our previous forecast, indicating the speed and scale of the downside seen over late May and June. Taking this into account, we cut our H2 profit forecast by c44% or £7.6m, to leave full year profit expectations of £38.7m (previously £53.1m). While comparatives weaken materially in H2 for new car sales, the timing of the next Brexit deadline has the potential to be highly disruptive, hence our conservative take on both new and used car demand, and used car margins. For 2020FY, we have made similar downgrades and now forecast PBT of £39.9m (previously £54.1m), EPS 7.6p.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Downgrade to Hold and TP 45p. With the FCA now conducting an investigation into the group’s sales processes between 1 January 2016 and 13 June 2019, the shares are unlikely to move forward until this has been concluded. Arguably the fall in market capitalisation of more than £150m will far eclipse the impact on the business from the review, its cost, the disruption and any potential investment in processes or fines. Nonetheless, with the shares now effectively sat in the waiting room until events conclude, we downgrade to Hold.

Whilst the economic environment and new car market cycle are clearly unhelpful, we
continue to see value in Lookers strong market positioning.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

The combination of multiple estimate cuts and the FCA investigation makes for a tough investment case and we think that investors will want some clarity on the FCA outcome/costs before seeing the longer term value in the business.

Lookers has had a track record of outperformance vs the market over the years and this momentum now seems to be lost. At the interims, we will be looking for more details on what management can do to rebuild momentum in the core business.

We think that market weakness in the used car market is a function of the strong run in prices over the past few years seeing some correction, as well as a slower consumer market. While visibility is low, we think that the market could stabilise later in the year. Brexit, and the impact on FX as well as consumer confidence, remains the biggest risk to the sector.

As of yesterday's close, on our revised estimates, the shares trade on a CY19E PE of 5.9x, with freehold property backing of c. £250m and greater than £50m long leasehold.

With capex peaking in FY19E at £33m and falling to £18m in FY20E, FCF should start to improve materially, albeit this is before any FCA related costs.

While we think that the consolidation theme still holds for the industry, we would be surprised to see Lookers participate until it has stabilised its own business.

We cut our price target from 119p to 68p. We continue to value the business on a blend of DCF (20%) and PE (80%). We have applied a 10% discount to the 5yr PE (vs a 10% premium previously), reflecting negative earnings momentum.

A 68p TP represents a 8.7x CY19E PE on what we think should be trough earnings. This keeps us at Buy.

Still early days, more drilling may be required: Hurricane needs sustainable
production of 6-12 months and potentially more wells drilled across its
assets to gain a more definitive understanding of the reservoir. While the
data collected so far is encouraging, it is still early days. Disappointing results
from the Warwick Deep due to a poorly connected network of fractures
demonstrates the high-risk nature of Hurricane’s operations. Hurricane is
pioneering fractured basement plays in the UK and as such, will require
more data to better understand the resource potential. We therefore believe
it is too early to derisk a full-field development potential at Lancaster and
keep our risk factors unchanged in the NAV.

BE11:59am

RBC incoming:

BE11:59am

PBT now expected to be $150-170m for H1 19
Hiscox released a trading update this morning, announcing that it expects
profit before tax of $150-170m for H1 19. The middle of this range is c.50%
lower than our original estimate of £324m for H1 19. The lower profit
guidance is driven by continued deterioration from 2018 catastrophe
events including Typhoon Jebi and Hurricane Michael, with the net impact
from reserve strengthening for these events being c.$40m. The company
also stated that it expects to recognise an additional tax provision of $60m
for H1 19, contributing to the lower profit. In its statement, Hiscox stated
that it does not anticipate any impact on the interim or final dividend.
Loss deterioration continues to impact the market
Claims deterioration on Typhoon Jebi and Hurricane Michael continues to
be reported by insurers in the market, with the estimated industry loss for
Jebi now at $16bn and Hurricane Michael now $12bn according to Hiscox.
According to Munich Re, in 2018 insured loss estimates were $9bn for
Typhoon Jebi, and $10bn for Hurricane Michael, so we anticipate that this
reserve deterioration will not just be limited to Hiscox.

A. M. @1966: thanks.
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE isn't Hiscox more the fact the insurance market's still dropping/under pressure. Claims...their reserves are more than adequate.
BE11:59am

Reserve deterioration should help pricing momentum
All in, we believe this should help pricing momentum going forward.
In Hiscox's statement, the insurer stated that market conditions are
improving, especially in the London market, where there is good rate
momentum. Following consecutive years of heavy losses, increased
discipline at Lloyd's following the Decile 10 initiative and now further
loss deterioration on 2018 catastrophe events, we see the firmer pricing
environment gaining momentum and lasting well into 2020. Our preferred
ways to play the firming market are Lancashire (Outperform), Beazley (Top
Pick) and AXA (Outperform),

BE12:00pm

Updating estimates and price target
Following the trading update we reduce our earnings estimates for 2019
by 40%. This is driven by the recognition of a $60m adverse tax provision,
as well as worse prior year loss estimates which include deterioration of
claims from Typhoon Jebi and Hurricane Michael. We reduce our 2020-21
estimates by 3% on average, due to lower investment returns. Our book
value estimates for 2019-21 reduce by 6% on average. We reduce our price
target to 1,625p and maintain our Sector Perform rating.
